title.narrative: 3MDGFund med fokus på mödrahälsa och barnhälsa
3MDGFund with focus on maternal and child health

description.narrative: The Three Millennium Development Goal Fund (3MDG) was established in 2012 by a consortium of international donors to address basic health needs of vulnerable people in Myanmar, and contribute to the country’s efforts to achieve the three health-related Millennium Development Goals. These three goals consist of reducing child mortality, improving maternal health and combating HIV, tuberculosis and malaria. 3MDG places special emphasis upon provision of quality maternal, newborn and child health services.

Insatsen är ett stöd till en givargemensam FN-fond(UNOPS/3MDG)med fokus på mödrahälsa(MDG5)och barnhälsa(MDG4)i Burma/Myanmar. Genom stärkande av det nationella hälsosystemet samt samordning av aktörer från det civila samhället, FN-organen och hälsoministeriet med fokus på särskilt utsatta områden skall insatsen bidra till att minska mödradödligheten och barnadödligheten i Burma/Myanmar.

The contribution is a support to a donorcoordinated UN-fund (UNOPS/3MDG) with focus on maternal health (MDG5) and child health (MDG4)in Burma/Myanmar. Strengthening the national health system and coordination of actors from civil society, the UN-system and the ministry of health with focus on hard-to-reach areas will contribute to decrease maternal mortality and child mortality in Burma/Myanmar.

participating-org.narrative: UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services
UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Three Millennium Development Goal Fund (3MDG) was established in 2012 by a consortium of international donors to address basic health needs in Myanmar in particular to contribute to the country’s efforts to achieve the three health-related Millennium Development Goals. For example, the percentage of pregnant women who had a skilled birth attendant increased from 56% to 60% from 2013 to 2018, and post-natal and newborn care coverage increased from 58% to 76% during the same period. These are incremental but important improvements, and mean that women living in townships that 3MDG supports are more likely to have safe, healthy pregnancies. The Fund has particularly focused on addressing the the wide disparities between urban and ruralareas, and between and within states and regions. Developments are more pronounced at state and regional level, for example access to maternal, newborn and child health services increased for between 15-20% of the township population in 34 townships in Myanmar. Some examples of cumulative nation-wide results: - 280,683 women received ante-natal care (four visits per woman) - 265,583 births were attended by a skilled health personnel - 379,260 infants were vaccinated against measles - 87,882 life-saving referrals for pregnant women - 70,926 life-saving referrals for children under five - 316,134 women received postnatal and newborn care within three daysTo help build a more efficient and responsive system, health systems strengthening efforts at national, state and region and township levels were a priority. At the policy level, 3MDG made a strategic contribution to the development and implementation of the Myanmar National Health Plan (2017-21) through an inclusive process, and also to the National Health Plan Implementation Monitoring Unit (NIMU). Improving human resources for health was a focus area and notable results includes the establishment and upgrading of skills labs in all midwifery schools, strengthened accreditation, and better trained faculty members for stronger, more confidentmidwifery staff. Significant results were made in communicable diseases, especially in malaria, where Myanmar has reduced prevalence and death rate by enormous amounts over the lifetime of the Fund. During the 3MDG Fund’s lifetime, and as a result of multiple coordinated interventions by government and non-government actors, there was a 98% reduction in malaria deaths, and declining prevalence. The malaria test positivity rate decreased from 28.76 in 2013 to 3.47 in 2017.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
